history.content:
I loved CS164. It's a great mix of theory and programming. One twitter user described compilers as "theory dressed as systems". I took it with Koushik Sen, and had a great time. It's not math as you would normally expect, but it turns out that formalizing concepts that come up in compilers is really useful for accurately specifying behaviors. It's much closer to CS61B than 170, and only briefly touches upon graph coloring, but that's not the focus of the course. The course really teaches you to build an end to end system, and I learned a ton about software from the course. You implement a compiler for a subset of python, called chocopy (like the snack). https://chocopy.org/ The last project is about code generation for RISC V (the compiler you will build takes chocopy code and produces RISC V assembly), so it is important to brush up the 61C around the last third of the class.


--+-


Currently taking the class with Hilfinger. The class is a mix of theory and systems, which I like a lot. However, unlike 162 much of the material is not explicitly required in interviews or most areas as a SWE, unless you plan to build, contribute to, or directly work with a parser or compiler (which is possible for some optimization projects, but a bit niche). However, if you're interested in systems at all definitely take the class. It seems like if you take it in the fall you can still do 162 in the spring, so I would recommend that.

I loved CS164. It's a great mix of theory and programming. One twitter user described compilers as "theory dressed as systems". I took it with Koushik Sen, and had a great time. It's not math as you would normally expect, but it turns out that formalizing concepts that come up in compilers is really useful for accurately specifying behaviors. It's much closer to CS61B than 170, and only briefly touches upon graph coloring, but that's not the focus of the course. The course really teaches you to build an end to end system, and I learned a ton about software from the course. You implement a compiler for a subset of python, called chocopy (like the snack). https://chocopy.org/ The last project is about code generation for RISC V (the compiler you will build takes chocopy code and produces RISC V assembly), so it is important to brush up the 61C around the last third of the class.

children.subject: Yeah that's fine, I don't think 162 is huge for recruiting in my experience. 164 is just as rewarding for training programming skills (although you won't be using c pointers, you will be dealing with explicit memory management on the stack and heap, garbage collection, and more). If 164 isn't offered in the spring, then it's definitely beneficial to take it in the fall, and to take CS162 in the spring.
Okay thanks a lot for such detailed answer!

For student answer above, as II'm graduating next year, do you think it's fine if I take 162 in my last semester instead of taking it this Fall? (But if I take 162 this Fall, I won't be able to take 164).

history.content:
I am rising senior interested in taking CS164. Since 164 is not offered in Spring 2020 on draft schedule, would it be okay if I take 164 this Fall 2019 and 162 in Spring 2020, in terms of recruiting point of view?

Also, can more people comment about 164? Is there much math or theory, compared to programming? I hate 70 and 170 but I like 61B.
history.subject: CS 164 or CS 162
